p.s: Throughout the whole novel conflict of identity is thematized.
In this excerpt it is mimaday shown through narrative techniques and perspectives, which are for example first person narrator, flashback and tensed atmosphere.

s.add: The effect of them will be analysed in the following.

p.s: Mainly the whole novel is written in a first person narrator perspective, the reader has a limited point of view.
In this perspective the author makes use of the personal pronoun I, which underlines the point of view.
As a combination of this points the reader is very attached emotionally connected / attached to the plot and to the character, which is in this case Starr the protagonist.

Typically for the first person anrrator as the protagonist is also that the readers get to know about thoughts, feelings and motivations of the narrator, through which he get first-hand information and impressions towards the plot.
One also has to keep in mind that through the limited point of view important information could get left out e.g. motivations, feelings, etc. of other characters.
In terms of narrative techniques one has to mention that the author made use of many direct speeches.

Direct speeches like a hairbrush is not a gun (l. 8), 'Starr', she says, making her way over.'What are you doing out here' (l. 26) bring the plot closer to the reader, because it creates a feeling, as onesoflt would be in this scene.

The interior monologue in line 5 to line 7, which is a part stream-of-consciousnessstream of consciousness, which is a part of the means of presentation term for a specific style of narration, allows the reader to know thoughts of Starr, which is supportive to understand Starr.
One can find another thought in line 48, in which Starr convinces and forces herself to speak in front of the crowd, her friends and the police.
This scene is also supportive for the understanding of Starr, because there, in this scene, one could see that she puts her fears under the public welfare, even though she has to overcome herself.
Another narrative technique is the flashback between line 19 and line 22.

Here the author switches between past and presence, as one hsould in a flashback normally used to bring aan event from the past closer to the reader, to underline how deep the effect of Khalil's murder for Starr is - she has to think about it again and again.

add.s: So one could say that through this scene, one can understand Starr more - and the effect Khalil's murder has.

p.s: If one refers to mode of presentation panoramic many events described in a short way and scenic many details, short amount of time, one has to classify this one as a scenic description.
Especially the first three lines are pretty much detailed.
In line 29 the author also makes use of another technique - the fore-shadowingforeshadowing, in which events, which take a place in the future, are teased.
Here Ms. Ofrah brings up the point of Starr's biggest voice and thought the fact that Ms. Ofrah herself yelled through the hellhorn one automatically is teased and thrilled if Starr will do this too.
Tensel is also the whole atmosphere in this excerpt, which is probably created through many direct speeches and the situation, in which protestors are facing cops.
All in all, one could say that the state of mind Starr is presented through many diffrentdifferent narrative techniques and the whole way of narration.
The biggest impact on this discriptiondescription is probably created through the interior monologue and the flashbacks.
